block.usage: Adds 2 or more inputs. All the input pads will inherit the type of the output pad.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Ambient light shader.

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: power
output.description: val = A raised to the power x

block.usage: Returns "base" raised to "exponent".

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: Cell noise value at point p

block.usage: Cellnoise returns a random value between 0 and "amplitude" for each integer "cell". It's much cheaper than calling noise.

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: Clamp a between min and max

block.usage: Clamps the first argument between the minimum and maximum values provided.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Cook-Torrance specular term. The "distribution" variable controls the microfacet distribution function being used, being 0 = Beckmann (default), 1 = Ward, 2 = Trowbridge-Reitz, 3 = Heidrich-Seidel (anisotropic). The "attenuation" variable controls the geometric attenuation function being used, being 0 = the default shadowing/masking function proposed by Blinn for the Torrance-Sparrow model, 1 = the approximation suggested by Christophe Schlick for the first Smith shadowing/masking equation for a known microfacet normal, 2 = full Smith second equation for an averaged microfacet normal (as used in the He-Torrance model). In the case of the Heidrich-Seidel anisotropic distribution, some literature mentions adding an isotropic specular term, which is added here via "specularbrdf", but the user might want to override this in the respective header - this distribution uses the anisotropy direction defined by "direction", which defaults to the global variable "dPdv". The specular color value is passed to "aov_specularcolor", while the specular value is passed to the "aov_specular" AOV presets. The Fresnel term used is the complex Fresnel function, from the Odforce.net Odwiki, courtesy of Mario Marengo and the Odforce community, using the "ior" index of refraction, and the "extinction" extinction coefficient. The "category" variable defines the light categories used for the "illuminance" construct of this block.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Cook-Torrance specular term. The "distribution" variable controls the microfacet distribution function being used, being 0 = Beckmann (default), 1 = Ward, 2 = Trowbridge-Reitz, 3 = Heidrich-Seidel (anisotropic). The "attenuation" variable controls the geometric attenuation function being used, being 0 = the default shadowing/masking function proposed by Blinn for the Torrance-Sparrow model, 1 = the approximation suggested by Christophe Schlick for the first Smith shadowing/masking equation for a known microfacet normal, 2 = full Smith second equation for an averaged microfacet normal (as used in the He-Torrance model). In the case of the Heidrich-Seidel anisotropic distribution, some literature mentions adding an isotropic specular term, which is added here via "specularbrdf", but the user might want to override this in the respective header - this distribution uses the anisotropy direction defined by "direction", which defaults to the global variable "dPdv". The specular color value is passed to "aov_specularcolor", while the specular value is passed to the "aov_specular" AOV presets. The Fresnel term used is the complex Fresnel function, from the Odforce.net Odwiki, courtesy of Mario Marengo and the Odforce community, using the "ior" index of refraction, and the "extinction" extinction coefficient. The "category" variable defines the light categories used for the "illuminance" construct of this block.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Cook-Torrance specular term. The "distribution" variable controls the microfacet distribution function being used, being 0 = Beckmann (default), 1 = Ward, 2 = Trowbridge-Reitz, 3 = Heidrich-Seidel (anisotropic). The "attenuation" variable controls the geometric attenuation function being used, being 0 = the default shadowing/masking function proposed by Blinn for the Torrance-Sparrow model, 1 = the approximation suggested by Christophe Schlick for the first Smith shadowing/masking equation for a known microfacet normal, 2 = full Smith second equation for an averaged microfacet normal (as used in the He-Torrance model). In the case of the Heidrich-Seidel anisotropic distribution, some literature mentions adding an isotropic specular term, which is added here via "specularbrdf", but the user might want to override this in the respective header - this distribution uses the anisotropy direction defined by "direction", which defaults to the global variable "dPdv". The specular color value is passed to "aov_specularcolor", while the specular value is passed to the "aov_specular" AOV presets. The Fresnel term used is the complex Fresnel function, from the Odforce.net Odwiki, courtesy of Mario Marengo and the Odforce community, using the "ior" index of refraction, and the "extinction" extinction coefficient. The "category" variable defines the light categories used for the "illuminance" construct of this block.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Divides input A by input B.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Returns the dot product of two vectors, the sum of the products of each component of the two vectors.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Returns the dot product of two vectors, the sum of the products of each component of the two vectors.

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: value of smoothstep function at x

block.rsl_code: #define stype_$(minimum:type) 1 #if RENDERER == prman $(value) = smoothstep( $(minimum), $(maximum), $(x) ); #else #ifdef stype_float $(value) = smoothstep( $(minimum), $(maximum), $(x) ); #else $(value) = color( smoothstep(comp( $(minimum),0),comp( $(maximum),0),comp( $(x), 0)), smoothstep(comp( $(minimum),1),comp( $(maximum),1),comp( $(x), 1)), smoothstep(comp( $(minimum),2),comp( $(maximum),2),comp( $(x), 2))); #endif /* stype_$(minimum:type) */ #endif /* RENDERER */ #undef stype_$(minimum:type)
block.usage: Result is zero if "x" is less than "minimum", one if "x" is greater than "maximum", otherwise it is interpolated between zero and one with a smooth Hermite curve. If the type is color, then it operates on a component basis.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Return the reflection coefficient Kr and the refraction (or transmission) coefficient "Kt", given an incident direction "I", the surface normal "N", and the relative index of refraction "eta". Eta is the ratio of the index of refraction in the volume containing the incident vector, to that of the volume being entered. These coefficients are computed using the Fresnel formula. This function also returns the reflected "R" and transmitted "T" vectors.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Incident ray direction. The availability of this global variable for the different shading contexts is renderer specific.

block.author: rconstruct

input.name: x
input.description: Condition value, true if non-zero, false if zero

input.name: true_value
input.description: Input value to pass through if x is true

input.name: false_value
input.description: Input value to pass through if exp is false

output.name: value
output.description: if condition is true then this is true_value, otherwise it is false_value

block.usage: The value of "x" is a float that determines which input value is passed to the output. Any non-zero value is regarded as true.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Returns 1 if A is lower than B, else returns 0.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Returns the maximum of the arguments given. When evaluating point type variables, the arguments will be evaluated on a component basis.

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: The resulting mix between A and B

block.usage: Mix returns x*(1-a)+y*a, that is, it performs a linear blend between values A and B. The types of A and B must be identical, but may be any of float, point, vector, normal, or color. The variants that operate on colors or point-like objects operate on a component by component basis (e.g: separately for x, y, and z).

output.name: value

block.usage: Mix returns x*(1-a)+y*a, that is, it performs a linear blend between values A and B. The types of A and B must be identical, but may be any of float, point, vector, normal, or color. The variants that operate on colors or point-like objects operate on a component by component basis (e.g: separately for x, y, and z).

block.rib_statements:
Hider "raytrace" "int jitter" [1]
Option "trace" "int maxdepth" [10] Option "trace" "int diffuseraycache" [1]
Attribute "visibility" "int trace" [1] Attribute "visibility" "int diffuse" [1] Attribute "visibility" "int specular" [1] Attribute "visibility" "int transmission" [1]
Attribute "shade" "string diffusehitmode" ["shader"] Attribute "shade" "string specularhitmode" ["shader"] Attribute "shade" "string transmissionhitmode" ["shader"]
Attribute "trace" "int diffusemaxdepth" [4] Attribute "trace" "int specularmaxdepth" [4]
Attribute "light" "string shadows" ["on"]
Attribute "user" "int lightsamples" [16] # arealights Attribute "user" "int gi_light_samples" [128] # GI
Option "user" "string gi_light_envmap" ["/home/cgwork/OSS/HDRIs/uffizi-large.hdr"] Option "user" "string gi_light_envspace" ["world"]

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: Point, vector, or normal with the specified components

block.usage: Sets the X, Y, and Z components of a point, vector, or normal.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Note that unlike the operators in the Renderman shading language the result is always the same type as the inputs. Also both inputs must be of the same type. The operation is done in parallel for each component.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Note that unlike the operators in the Renderman shading language the result is always the same type as the inputs. Also both inputs must be of the same type. The operation is done in parallel for each component.

block.author: rconstruct

input.name: P
input.description: Point, vector or normal to transform

input.name: from_space
input.description: The coordinate system to transform from

input.name: to_space
input.description: The coordinate system to transform into

input.name: Matrix
input.description: Use this matrix instead of a predefined coordinate system

output.name: Pout
output.description: The transformed point, vector or normal

block.rsl_code:
#ifdef TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS #undef TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS #endif
#define Matrix_$(Matrix) #ifdef Matrix_UND #define TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS $(to_space) #else #define TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS $(Matrix) #endif /* Matrix_UND */
#define $(blockname)_$(P:type) 1 #ifdef $(blockname)_point $(Pout) = transform( $(from_space), TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS , $(P) ); #elif $(blockname)_vector $(Pout) = vtransform( $(from_space), TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS , $(P) ); #elif $(blockname)_normal $(Pout) = ntransform( $(from_space), TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS , $(P) ); #endif /* $(blockname)_$(P:type) */ #undef $(blockname)_$(P:type)
#undef Matrix_$(Matrix) #undef TRANSFORM_ARGUMENTS
block.usage: A block for the "transform", "vtransform" and "ntransform" functions, to transform the supplied point "P", vector "V" or normal "N" respectively, from the coordinate system "fromspace" to the coordinate system "tospace", with "fromspace" defaulting to "current". Note that "current" is implementation specific. Predefined coordinate systems are: "current", "object", "shader", "world", "camera", "screen", "raster" and "NDC". A transformation matrix might be given instead of a "tospace" coordinate system. User defined coordinate systems can also be refered to.

block.author: rconstruct

input.name: gain
input.description: Controls the contrast of the turbulence

block.usage: 3 dimensional turbulence fractal function with Perlin noise basis. Returns a result in the [0,1] range by default.

block.author: rconstruct

output.name: value
output.description: The resulting mix between A and B

block.usage: Mix returns x*(1-a)+y*a, that is, it performs a linear blend between values A and B. The types of A and B must be identical, but may be any of float, point, vector, normal, or color. The variants that operate on colors or point-like objects operate on a component by component basis (e.g: separately for x, y, and z).

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: 3D Voronoi cell noise, 2 features version. When "metric" = 0, distance metric is Tchebychev otherwise the distance metric = Minkowski, being "metric", Minkowski's P parameter, with P = 1 as the Manhattan metric, P = 2, the Euclidian metric, and allowing higher orders of P. Note that as P increases, it tends towards the Tchebychev result.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Useful for supplying multiple inputs with the same value.

block.author: rconstruct
block.usage: Note that in all shading contexts, "P" is the surface position, the only exception being volume shaders, in which "P" is the light ray origin. Also note that in imager shaders, "P" is the position of the pixel center in raster space, with the z coordinate being 0.
